Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Theoretical Foundations of Interaction Nanoparticle Chromatography

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510993
Neimark

This GOALI award is for the collaboration between Rutgers University and DuPont Corporation and supports research and education to develop theoretical foundations for separation of functionalized nanoparticles (NP) using a new technique of interaction nanoparticle chromatography (INPC). The PIs will systematically study for the first time the specifics of NP adhesion and mobility with specially designed theoretical and computational tools based on the hybrid dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) and Monte Carlo (MC) simulation techniques. These methods will be applied to and tested against experimental data collected at DuPont on separation of functionalized silica NPs on polymer-grafted monolith columns.

The success of the proposed project will enable a strategic approach to guided optimization of INPC conditions for improved NP characterization, separations, and purification. The results of this research will have a significant transformative interdisciplinary impact for simulation and optimization of various complex NP-polymer composite systems and processes and a rational design of novel nanocomposites, NP-based drug delivery vehicles, and pharmaceutical gels and films.

The results of this work will be disseminated by creating a dedicated webpage for making project reports and presentations available for educational purposes. The computational programs together with several instructive case study examples will be posted on the webpage for free distribution among the scientific community. The students will benefit from industrial training and research facilities of DuPont Experimental Station. Guided by the industrial Co-PI, they will produce computer programs of practical relevance and get a hands-on experience in NP and chromatographic experimentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emerging technologies of NP production and processing require advanced methods of NP characterization and separation. While various methods are available for NP separation by size, there are no efficient methods for NP separation by surface chemistry. The promicing method is a new technique of interaction nanoparticle chromatography (INPC) on porous substrates grafted with polymer brushes (PB). The main obstacle in developing efficient INPC processes is the absence of adequate theoretical and computational models describing the adhesion and flow of NPs within PB-grafted pore channels. This complex process is governed by polymer-substrate and polymer-NP entropic and enthalpic interactions, affected by density and length of grafted chains, pore size and shape, as well as solvent composition and temperature, which can be varied to optimize the separation.

This GOALI award for collaboration between Rutgers University and DuPont Corporation aims at designing novel computational methods, based on coarse-grained Monte Carlo (MC) and dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) simulation techniques, capable of predicting equilibrium partitioning and dynamics of functionalized NPs on PB-grafted substrates and to advance fundamental understanding of the physico-chemical mechanisms of NP retention in INPC. The developed methods are applied to and tested against experimental data on NP separation on polymer-grafted monolithic columns. The GOALI grant is enhanced by the INTERN supplements to support PhD student training at DuPont and EXEDE grants to provide HPC resources.

 

Intellectual merit

The fundamental outcome is the validation of our hypothesis that NP separation by surface chemistry can be efficiently performed on PB-grafted porous substrates in the regime of critical adsorption, which is found efficient in polymer chromatography. The regime of critical adsorption is conditioned by the balance between the entropic and enthalpic contributions and is characterized by the size-independent elution. Using extensive dissipative particle dynamics simulations, we consider adhesion of NPs functionalized by hydrophilic and hydrophobic ligands to PBs, which conformation are controlled by the solvent quality varied by the solvent composition. Our findings demonstrate that, with the decrease of solvent quality, controlled by the solvent composition, NP elution undergoes a critical adsorption transition from the enthalpy dominated size-exclusion with larger particles having shorter reteention time to the enthaply dominated adsorption modes with the reversal of the elution order. The critical point of adsorption that strongly depends on the NP functionalization. Using the dynamic model of NP dispersion, we show that NPs can be effectively separated by surface chemistry, using the gradient mode of INPC with controlled variation of the solvent composition.

Other important findings include the determination of the critical conditions of polymer adsorption and chromatography on porous and nonporous substrates and the establishment of a scaling relationship for predicting the retension time of NPs depending on the ration of the NP size and the hydrodynamic pore width. The latter relationship is confirmed by the experimental data for NPs and channels that differ in size by 3 orders of magnitude. This agreement confirms that the results of simulations can be used for modeling experimental systems for NP separations on polymer-grafted capillaries and columns grafted with polymers.

 

Broader impact

      The results of this research enable a strategic approach to guided optimization of the INPC conditions for improved characterization, separations, and purification of NPs. The computational models developed have been implemented in a novel INPC system for separation of functionalized NPs at the industrial Co-PI lab. They have a significant transformative interdisciplinary impact since the problems of adhesion and flow of NPs in nanoscale environments are common across different chemical and biomedical technologies. Improved understanding of the physico-chemical mechanisms of interactions of functionalized NPs with polymers and nanostructured substrates is the key for a rational design of novel nanocomposites, NP-based drug delivery vehicles, and pharmaceutical gels and films. The developed innovative modeling tools can be adapted and employed for simulation and optimization of various complex NP-polymer composite systems and processes beyond INPC.

The project provided opportunity for training two  PhD and one MS students, who successfully defended their dissertations and found desirable employment (1 as a faculty member and 2 - in industry), one postdoctoral fellow and two undergradute (one minority, one female) REU trainees.  The student training was facilitated by the professional interactions with the industrial Co-PI and the memberes of DuPont chromatography team. Internship at DuPont helped students to apply the computational simulation skills that he developed to real-world industrial problems, to get hands-on experience with experimental studies, and to understand better the specifics of the industrial working environment. The project results were documented in 6 archival papers in high-impact journals, three of which featured on the journal covers, 2 PhD and 1MS dissertations, and presented at 8 national and international scientific meetings and 6 invited lectures and seminars. Educational videos are posted on the dedicated YouTube channels. The novel simulation methods and case-study systems are included into the graduate course on "Nanoscale Thermodynamics and Transport".
